trans-unit.source: Access an Azure API App using HTML and JavaScript
trans-unit.target: Access an Azure API App using HTML and JavaScript

trans-unit.source: Learn how to access your API App back-end using HTML and JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to access your API App back-end using HTML and JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Consume an Azure API App using HTML and JavaScript
trans-unit.target: Consume an Azure API App using HTML and JavaScript

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This article shows how to create an HTML and JavaScript client for an [API app](app-service-api-apps-why-best-platform.md) in [Azure App Service](/documentation/services/app-service/).
trans-unit.target: This article shows how to create an HTML and JavaScript client for an [API app](app-service-api-apps-why-best-platform.md) in [Azure App Service](/documentation/services/app-service/).

trans-unit.source: The article assumes a working knowledge of HTML and JavaScript, and uses the [AngularJS](https://angularjs.org/) JavaScript framework for making REST calls to the API App.
trans-unit.target: The article assumes a working knowledge of HTML and JavaScript, and uses the [AngularJS](https://angularjs.org/) JavaScript framework for making REST calls to the API App.

trans-unit.source: Some articles to go through before this to help you get started.
trans-unit.target: Some articles to go through before this to help you get started.

trans-unit.source: In [Create an API App](app-service-dotnet-create-api-app.md), you created an API App project.
trans-unit.target: In [Create an API App](app-service-dotnet-create-api-app.md), you created an API App project.

trans-unit.source: In [Deploy an API App](app-service-dotnet-deploy-api-app.md), you deploy the API app to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: In [Deploy an API App](app-service-dotnet-deploy-api-app.md), you deploy the API app to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: In [Debug an API App](../app-service-dotnet-remotely-debug-api-app.md), you use Visual Studio to remotely debug the code while it runs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In [Debug an API App](../app-service-dotnet-remotely-debug-api-app.md), you use Visual Studio to remotely debug the code while it runs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: This article will build upon these previous articles by demonstrating how your HTML applications can use JavaScript to access your back-end API apps.
trans-unit.target: This article will build upon these previous articles by demonstrating how your HTML applications can use JavaScript to access your back-end API apps.

trans-unit.source: Enabling CORS
trans-unit.target: Enabling CORS

trans-unit.source: Typically, CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) is needed in HTML applications that will be served from different hosts than the API itself.
trans-unit.target: Typically, CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) is needed in HTML applications that will be served from different hosts than the API itself.

trans-unit.source: With API Apps, there are at least two options for enabling CORS.
trans-unit.target: With API Apps, there are at least two options for enabling CORS.

trans-unit.source: This section will outline these options.
trans-unit.target: This section will outline these options.

trans-unit.source: Enabling CORS for API App Gateways
trans-unit.target: Enabling CORS for API App Gateways

trans-unit.source: API App Gateways can be configured to enable CORS using the Azure preview portal.
trans-unit.target: API App Gateways can be configured to enable CORS using the Azure preview portal.

trans-unit.source: By adding the **MS_CrossDomainOrigins** *appSetting* you can specify which URLs are allowed to call your API App.
trans-unit.target: By adding the **MS_CrossDomainOrigins** *appSetting* you can specify which URLs are allowed to call your API App.

trans-unit.source: This section will explain how to use this *appSetting* to enable CORS at the API Gateway level.
trans-unit.target: This section will explain how to use this *appSetting* to enable CORS at the API Gateway level.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the Azure preview portal blade for the API App you want to CORS-enable.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the Azure preview portal blade for the API App you want to CORS-enable.

trans-unit.source: Once there, click the *Gateway* icon for your API App.
trans-unit.target: Once there, click the *Gateway* icon for your API App.

trans-unit.source: Clicking the API App Gateway button
trans-unit.target: Clicking the API App Gateway button

trans-unit.source: Click the **Gateway Host** link in the portal blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Gateway Host** link in the portal blade.

trans-unit.source: Clicking the API App Gateway host link
trans-unit.target: Clicking the API App Gateway host link

trans-unit.source: Click the **All Settings** link in the portal blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the **All Settings** link in the portal blade.

trans-unit.source: Gateway All Settings link
trans-unit.target: Gateway All Settings link

trans-unit.source: Click the **Application Settings** button in the portal blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Application Settings** button in the portal blade.

trans-unit.source: Gateway application settings
trans-unit.target: Gateway application settings

trans-unit.source: Add the **MS_CrossDomainOrigins** application setting.
trans-unit.target: Add the **MS_CrossDomainOrigins** application setting.

trans-unit.source: Make the value of the setting the comma-separated list of HTTP hosts you want to provide access to your API App.
trans-unit.target: Make the value of the setting the comma-separated list of HTTP hosts you want to provide access to your API App.

trans-unit.source: If you want to provide access to multiple hosts, the value of the *appSetting* can be set to something like the code below.
trans-unit.target: If you want to provide access to multiple hosts, the value of the *appSetting* can be set to something like the code below.

trans-unit.source: The section below will walk through the process of creating a separate web application containing a simple HTML page that calls the API App from a Web App running in the same Azure Resource Group as the API App.
trans-unit.target: The section below will walk through the process of creating a separate web application containing a simple HTML page that calls the API App from a Web App running in the same Azure Resource Group as the API App.

trans-unit.source: Since this is the only host that will be allowed access to the API App, the setting will be set to contain one host.
trans-unit.target: Since this is the only host that will be allowed access to the API App, the setting will be set to contain one host.

trans-unit.source: The screen shot below demonstrates how this setting should look once you've saved it in the Azure preview portal.
trans-unit.target: The screen shot below demonstrates how this setting should look once you've saved it in the Azure preview portal.

trans-unit.source: The **MS_CrossDomainOrigins** application setting is discussed in detail in the blog post [Azure Mobile Service .NET Updates](http://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/07/28/azure-mobile-services-net-updates/), so check this post for more details on the details of the setting.
trans-unit.target: The **MS_CrossDomainOrigins** application setting is discussed in detail in the blog post [Azure Mobile Service .NET Updates](http://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/07/28/azure-mobile-services-net-updates/), so check this post for more details on the details of the setting.

trans-unit.source: Enabling CORS in Web API Code
trans-unit.target: Enabling CORS in Web API Code

trans-unit.source: The process of enabling CORS in Web API is documented in the ASP.NET article [Enabling Cross-Origin Requests in ASP.NET Web API 2](http://www.asp.net/web-api/overview/security/enabling-cross-origin-requests-in-web-api) in depth.
trans-unit.target: The process of enabling CORS in Web API is documented in the ASP.NET article [Enabling Cross-Origin Requests in ASP.NET Web API 2](http://www.asp.net/web-api/overview/security/enabling-cross-origin-requests-in-web-api) in depth.

trans-unit.source: For API Apps built using ASP.NET Web API the process is exactly the same but will be summarized below.
trans-unit.target: For API Apps built using ASP.NET Web API the process is exactly the same but will be summarized below.

trans-unit.source: Skip this section if you've already enabled CORS, as your API App should already be set up properly.
trans-unit.target: Skip this section if you've already enabled CORS, as your API App should already be set up properly.

trans-unit.source: CORS functionality is provided by the [Microsoft.AspNet.WebApi.Cors](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.AspNet.WebApi.Cors/) NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: CORS functionality is provided by the [Microsoft.AspNet.WebApi.Cors](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.AspNet.WebApi.Cors/) NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: Install it by opening the **Package Manager Console**, and execute the following PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: Install it by opening the **Package Manager Console**, and execute the following PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: Once the command executes, the Package Manager Console and **packages.config** will reflect the addition of the new NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: Once the command executes, the Package Manager Console and **packages.config** will reflect the addition of the new NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Open up the *App_Start/WebApiConfig.cs* file.
trans-unit.target: Open up the *App_Start/WebApiConfig.cs* file.

trans-unit.source: Add the line of code below to the **Register** method of the **WebApiConfig** class in the file.
trans-unit.target: Add the line of code below to the **Register** method of the **WebApiConfig** class in the file.

trans-unit.source: Once the file is updated the code should look like the following:
trans-unit.target: Once the file is updated the code should look like the following:

trans-unit.source: The final step to enable CORS is to demarcate the individual action methods you want to enable.
trans-unit.target: The final step to enable CORS is to demarcate the individual action methods you want to enable.

trans-unit.source: Add the **EnableCors** attribute over each of the methods or on the entire controller, as demonstrated in the code below.
trans-unit.target: Add the **EnableCors** attribute over each of the methods or on the entire controller, as demonstrated in the code below.

trans-unit.source: **Note**: Use of wildcards for all of the parameters with the EnableCors attribute is intended only for demonstration purposes, and will open your API up to all origins and all HTTP requests.
trans-unit.target: **Note**: Use of wildcards for all of the parameters with the EnableCors attribute is intended only for demonstration purposes, and will open your API up to all origins and all HTTP requests.

trans-unit.source: Please use this attribute with caution and understand the implications.
trans-unit.target: Please use this attribute with caution and understand the implications.

trans-unit.source: If you'd already deployed your API App to Azure prior to adding support for CORS, re-deploy the code so that CORS will be enabled in your Azure-hosted API.
trans-unit.target: If you'd already deployed your API App to Azure prior to adding support for CORS, re-deploy the code so that CORS will be enabled in your Azure-hosted API.

trans-unit.source: Creating a Web App to Consume the API App
trans-unit.target: Creating a Web App to Consume the API App

trans-unit.source: In this section, you'll create a new Empty Web Application, install and use AngularJS into it, and bind a simple HTML front end to the API App.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you'll create a new Empty Web Application, install and use AngularJS into it, and bind a simple HTML front end to the API App.

trans-unit.source: You'll deploy the consuming Web App into Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: You'll deploy the consuming Web App into Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: The HTML Web App will bind to and display the data retrieved from the API App, and provide users a simple UI for the Contacts API.
trans-unit.target: The HTML Web App will bind to and display the data retrieved from the API App, and provide users a simple UI for the Contacts API.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the solution that you created earlier in [Create an API App](app-service-dotnet-create-api-app.md), and select **Add -> New Project**
trans-unit.target: Right-click the solution that you created earlier in [Create an API App](app-service-dotnet-create-api-app.md), and select **Add -> New Project**

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Select the **ASP.NET Web Application** template.
trans-unit.target: Select the **ASP.NET Web Application** template.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Select the **Empty** template from the One ASP.NET dialog.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Empty** template from the One ASP.NET dialog.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Using either the **Package Manager** or by using the **Manage NuGet Packages** context menu item, install the [AngularJS](https://www.nuget.org/packages/angularjs) NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: Using either the **Package Manager** or by using the **Manage NuGet Packages** context menu item, install the [AngularJS](https://www.nuget.org/packages/angularjs) NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Using either the **Package Manager** or by using the **Manage NuGet Packages** context menu item, install the [Bootstrap](https://www.nuget.org/packages/bootstrap) NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: Using either the **Package Manager** or by using the **Manage NuGet Packages** context menu item, install the [Bootstrap](https://www.nuget.org/packages/bootstrap) NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Add a new HTML file to the Web App project.
trans-unit.target: Add a new HTML file to the Web App project.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Name the file *index.html*.
trans-unit.target: Name the file *index.html*.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Add the bootstrap CSS and AngularJS JavaScript files to the HTML page, as well as use a simple Bootstrap template ([like this one](http://getbootstrap.com/examples/starter-template/)) and create an empty script tag to prepare the page.
trans-unit.target: Add the bootstrap CSS and AngularJS JavaScript files to the HTML page, as well as use a simple Bootstrap template ([like this one](http://getbootstrap.com/examples/starter-template/)) and create an empty script tag to prepare the page.

trans-unit.source: Note: The comments in the HTML and JavaScript code below are preludes to subsequent steps in this section.
trans-unit.target: Note: The comments in the HTML and JavaScript code below are preludes to subsequent steps in this section.

trans-unit.source: Add the HTML table code shown below to the **container** *div* element in the HTML.
trans-unit.target: Add the HTML table code shown below to the **container** *div* element in the HTML.

trans-unit.source: In the `tbody` and `tfoot` elements replace each [ with { and each ] with }.
trans-unit.target: In the `tbody` and `tfoot` elements replace each [ with { and each ] with }.

trans-unit.source: (This site is currently unable to display double-curly-brace expressions in code blocks.)
trans-unit.target: (This site is currently unable to display double-curly-brace expressions in code blocks.)

trans-unit.source: Right-click the *index.html* file and click **Set as Start Page**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the *index.html* file and click **Set as Start Page**.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the *index.html* file and click **View in Browser**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the *index.html* file and click **View in Browser**.

trans-unit.source: Notice the template handlebars in the HTML output.
trans-unit.target: Notice the template handlebars in the HTML output.

trans-unit.source: You'll data-bind those HTML elements using AngularJS in the next step.
trans-unit.target: You'll data-bind those HTML elements using AngularJS in the next step.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Add the JavaScript code below to the *index.html* file to call the API and databind the HTML UI to the API output.
trans-unit.target: Add the JavaScript code below to the *index.html* file to call the API and databind the HTML UI to the API output.

trans-unit.source: 1, In the code you just added to index.html, replace the port number in the base URL (`http://localhost:1578`) with the actual port number for your API project.
trans-unit.target: 1, In the code you just added to index.html, replace the port number in the base URL (`http://localhost:1578`) with the actual port number for your API project.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the API App project is also running when you run the HTML client, or the JavaScript HTML will not function properly.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the API App project is also running when you run the HTML client, or the JavaScript HTML will not function properly.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the solution and select **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the solution and select **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: Then set both Web projects to **Start without Debugging**, and that the API project runs first.
trans-unit.target: Then set both Web projects to **Start without Debugging**, and that the API project runs first.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Run the solution and the HTML/JavaScript client connects to and displays data from the API App project.
trans-unit.target: Run the solution and the HTML/JavaScript client connects to and displays data from the API App project.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Deploying the Web App
trans-unit.target: Deploying the Web App

trans-unit.source: In this section you'll deploy the HTML/JavaScript client as an App Service Web App.
trans-unit.target: In this section you'll deploy the HTML/JavaScript client as an App Service Web App.

trans-unit.source: Once the deployment is complete, you'll change the URL the JavaScript is using to consume the deployed API App.
trans-unit.target: Once the deployment is complete, you'll change the URL the JavaScript is using to consume the deployed API App.

trans-unit.source: Note: This section assumes you've read and completed the [Deploy an API App](app-service-dotnet-deploy-api-app.md) article or you've previously deployed your own API App.
trans-unit.target: Note: This section assumes you've read and completed the [Deploy an API App](app-service-dotnet-deploy-api-app.md) article or you've previously deployed your own API App.

trans-unit.source: Open the API App's blade in the Azure preview portal.
trans-unit.target: Open the API App's blade in the Azure preview portal.

trans-unit.source: Click the URL in the blade to open it up in your browser.
trans-unit.target: Click the URL in the blade to open it up in your browser.

trans-unit.source: Once it opens, copy out the URL of the API App from the browser address bar.
trans-unit.target: Once it opens, copy out the URL of the API App from the browser address bar.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Paste the API App's URL to overwrite the previous value for the **$scope.baseUrl** property in the JavaScript code.
trans-unit.target: Paste the API App's URL to overwrite the previous value for the **$scope.baseUrl** property in the JavaScript code.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the URL specifies HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the URL specifies HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: The use of HTTPS is not optional; API Apps does not support HTTP.
trans-unit.target: The use of HTTPS is not optional; API Apps does not support HTTP.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the HTML/JavaScript Web Project and select the **Publish** context menu item.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the HTML/JavaScript Web Project and select the **Publish** context menu item.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Select the **Microsoft Azure Web Apps** option in the Publish Web dialog.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Microsoft Azure Web Apps** option in the Publish Web dialog.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Click the **New** button to create a new Web App.
trans-unit.target: Click the **New** button to create a new Web App.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Select the same App Hosting Plan and Resource Group in which your API App is already running.
trans-unit.target: Select the same App Hosting Plan and Resource Group in which your API App is already running.

trans-unit.source: **Note**: This isn't a requirement, but for demonstration purposes it makes it easier to clean up your Azure resources later if everything is contained in one Resource Group.
trans-unit.target: **Note**: This isn't a requirement, but for demonstration purposes it makes it easier to clean up your Azure resources later if everything is contained in one Resource Group.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Complete the Web Publish steps to deploy the HTML/JavaScript client to App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Complete the Web Publish steps to deploy the HTML/JavaScript client to App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Once the Web App is deployed it should automatically open in your Web browser and display the data from the API App.
trans-unit.target: Once the Web App is deployed it should automatically open in your Web browser and display the data from the API App.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: At this point, if you browse to the Resource Group you'll see the new Web App running alongside the API App.
trans-unit.target: At this point, if you browse to the Resource Group you'll see the new Web App running alongside the API App.

trans-unit.source: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: apiapp.json and Metadata in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: This example demonstrated how you can use AngularJS as your JavaScript platform for accessing API App back ends.
trans-unit.target: This example demonstrated how you can use AngularJS as your JavaScript platform for accessing API App back ends.

trans-unit.source: You can change the REST access functionality to use any other JavaScript framework.
trans-unit.target: You can change the REST access functionality to use any other JavaScript framework.

trans-unit.source: This example shows unauthenticated access to an API app.
trans-unit.target: This example shows unauthenticated access to an API app.

trans-unit.source: For information about authentication in App Service, see [Authentication for API apps and mobile apps](../app-service/app-service-authentication-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: For information about authentication in App Service, see [Authentication for API apps and mobile apps](../app-service/app-service-authentication-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
